awd_titl_txt: CSR:Small:A Server-Network Cooperative Approach to Data Center Energy Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
Fueled by the growth in cloud computing which serves critical application needs ranging from banking to national defense, data centers have become a critical part of our nation?s infrastructure . Within data centers, servers and the interconnect networks account for an increasingly significant portion of the overall energy. This is because many server farms are configured to operate at a capacity much higher than necessary, and the data movement between servers is rapidly increasing in volume. This project studies the interplay between the servers and networks, and devises energy-saving strategies through monitoring data center workload patterns. With the changing landscape of data center applications and their communication patterns, this research project offers a much-needed study through adopting a holistic view of energy consumed by both servers and networks. The research outcomes will provide direct benefit to US industry through minimizing data center energy.

This project investigates coordinated server-network energy optimization strategies that make judicious use of low-power states available in the processor and network component (micro) architectures while preserving application performance constraints. The solution approach seeks to design workload-specific energy management policies that select an optimal set of low power states and dynamic voltage/frequency settings that are best suited for the workload. To improve power efficiency, power shifting between heterogeneous components will be leveraged such that higher performance can be achieved within a specified power budget. The outcome of this research will include self-adaptive algorithms that will adjust themselves to the changing workload patterns, and techniques that minimize time-to-solution.

por.por_cntn:
Optimizing energy consumption in data centers involves judiciously exploiting the energy-saving mechanisms that are built into modern-day servers, and the associated network components such as switches and links. At the same time, most modern processors and network components have heterogeneous resources that need to be carefully used to take advantage of their performance potential (e.g., exploiting CPUs for parallelism and optical links for higher bandwidth needs). Fortunately, most components are already equipped with an abundant number of pre-built power-saving features such as sleep states, rate adaptation, power gating, and dynamic voltage/frequency scaling.

Our research project has developed a holistic energy optimization framework in data centers, exploiting power saving features all the way from the level of processors and platforms to clusters of server racks or pods.

Overall, our research accomplished three major outcomes:

1. Design of autonomous (self-adapting) algorithms for energy optimization in large-scale server farms

2. Exploration of holistic power and energy savings by combining servers and networks

3. Design and development of HolDCSim, an integrated simulator for data centers

Specifically, some of the prominent research findings of this project include the following:

 

-       PopCorns (ICCCN’18) is a cooperative server-network framework for power optimization along with job scheduling algorithms to place tasks onto servers in a power-aware manner. Our experiments show how the servers and network switches can take effective advantage of low-power states.

 

-       TS-BatPro (IEEE TGCN’19) is a novel framework that judiciously integrates spatial and temporal job batching strategies to save energy for multicore data center servers while meeting the QoS constraints for application workloads. Our results show that TS-BatPro is able to achieve significant amount of energy savings under various job response time constraints and traffic patterns.

 

-       PowerStar (IEEE Cloudcom’19) shows how to maximize power efficiency and reduce the number of reconfigurations needed in heterogeneous processors during periods of fluctuations in job arrival patterns while handling latency-critical workloads.

 

-       SpinSmart (ACM eEnergy’20) presents a framework that explores optimal server fan speeds to minimize the overall system energy consumption.

 

As broader impact, the project has presented solutions leading to a significantly better understanding of how servers and networks can coordinate with each other in order to holistically optimize energy consumption in data centers. A simulator infrastructure, HolDCSim, was made publicly available for researchers to explore effective data center energy management policies. The project also supported two undergraduate research scholars, both of whom have had an enriching experience with research publications.
